body: @MaajidKhan can you take a look? thanks.

@ledaiduongvnth Hello. 
so, I was able to compile your cpp code with OpenVINO and I was able to successfully do the inferencing on CPU.

If my understanding is correct, you were also able to successfully do the inferencing using OpenVINO but you had 2 concerns.

**1. warning with openvino.**
This warning actually comes from ngraph component of the openvino which is actually used to parse the onnx model, create a readable network before sending it to OpenVINO backend. This warning can be ignored. we will work with the OpenVINO team to suppress or fix this warning in the future releases.

**2.Memory Leak**
I would actually request you more information on how would I reproduce this memory leak from my end.

can you give me information on.
-> How did you detect this memory leak
-> can you provide me additional screenshots, stack traces or pointers.
-> Do you use any third party software like valgrind to detect these memory leaks

Any other information and detailed steps, so that I reproduce the memory leak at my end.

@MaajidKhan from my end, it is very easy to reproduce the problem. 
On 16 GB of Ram Machine, the program consumes most of the memory just after about` ~ 30 seconds( ~ 100 times of inference)` and outputs the following log continuously.
```
[WARN] 2021-04-12T02:42:00z ngraph/frontend/onnx_import/src/core/graph.cpp 98	Could not create an nGraph Constant for initializer '678'. Detailed error:
Check 'values.size() == 1 || values.size() == shape_size(m_shape)' failed at ngraph/core/include/ngraph/op/constant.hpp:69:
While validating node 'v0::Constant Constant_87663 () -> (f32{})' with friendly_name 'Constant_87663':
Did not get the expected number of literals for a constant of shape Shape{} (got 0, expected 1).
```
 I also notice that huge memory consumption comes from model Inference(I am not hands-on memory leak debug technics, so sorry). Note that the same program works fine on the same machine without Openvino support.
 
![Screenshot from 2021-04-12 09-42-11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28498007/114334694-538a8d00-9b75-11eb-823a-e885ea564f74.png)
@MaajidKhan could you reproduce the issue? please let me know!
Hi @ledaiduongvnth . I was able to reproduce this issue with your model and the code. I will try to debug further and get more details on this and post it here.

If you try something like this, the RAM memory won't shoot up just the cpu utilization will go up.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29036417/114707307-addb4780-9d47-11eb-9b9b-395c766342ec.png)
@MaajidKhan Thanks for your detailed explanation. Is there any way to walk around the issue? I really want to keep the input as the original size to improve accuracy.

@MaajidKhan
Such use case does exist, for example:
1. dynamic batch size
2. dynamic image width (in my case, an OCR text recognition model, with fixed image height and dynamic image width, as texts have different length)

My workaround for these two use cases:
1. split data into fixed batch-sizes, like [1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128]. For example, if the input data length is 200, it can be split into 128, 64, 8, so I can get the 200 results by three inferences, it is slower a little bit, but the RAM usage is predictable.
2. similar workaround for dynamic image width. Image height is fixed, with limited number of fixed widths (70, 140, 280, 560, 1120, 2240), for the tradeoff between speed and RAM usage.

ONNXRuntime + CUDA EP has no such issue, so I think it is a good improvement for OpenVINO to consider. With such improvement, we can have identical code for GPU(CUDA) and CPU(OpenVINO).
